SIMMONS:
All this could be quite salutary if the blame -were
placed where it belongs—on the narrow demands and
controls of the Communist Party itself and the fear
thereof which results in stupid conformity, instead of
on the bureaucratic servants who carry out the orders
of the Party. Soviet drama can never have any relevance
to the reality of life so long as the creative dramatist
must submit to the monolithic controls of the Communist
Party.
(IMPERSONAL, BRISK) Your name, sir?
Rodion Ivanov.
Date and place of birth?
I was born in 1896, in the village of Vilovatov, in the
Samara Government, Buzuluk County, Vilovatov Volost.
Family background?
My father was a peasant and worked on a farm.
How did you happen to leave the U.S.S.R.?
As a draftee I was taken prisoner by the Germans in 1941-
What was your occupation while in Russia?
I was a writer.
